During the morning returned to area and anchored off Lutong Town while sweeps continued operations. Underway at 1805 and stood out of area. In accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE dispatch 160247 of June 1945 USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON), USS SENTRY and USS SAUFLEY departed for Brunei Bay at 1900. At 2156 USS WALLER departed formation and Lieutenant Commander SILK in USS SAUFLEY became Officer in Tactical Command. USS WALLER rejoined at 2305 and Commander THOMPSON became Officer in Tactical Command.

June 18 Steaming in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) and USS SENTRY en route from Miri, Sarawak, to Brunei Bay, British North Borneo. During the morning entered Brunei Bay, proceeded into Victoria Harbor, and anchored at 0729.

Underway at 1601 in company with USS WALLER in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE dispatch 150509 and formed Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT NINETY SIX (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON in USS WALLER). At 1642 departed Brunei Bay for Morotai, Halmahera Group.

June 19 en route from Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, to Morotai, Halmahera Group, in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) as Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT NINETY SIX.

June 20 En route from Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, to Morotai, Halmahera Group, in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) as Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT NINETY SIX.

June 21 En route from Brunei Bay, British North Borneo, to Morotai, Halmahera Group, in company with USS WALLER (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander THOMPSON) as Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT ONE POINT NINETY SIX

During the morning entered Morotai Harbor, fueled, and anchored at 1017.
June 22 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai, Halmahera Group. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

June 2 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai, Halmahera Group. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH). Underway at 1212 in accordance with Commander Amphibious Group EIGHT Rehearsal Order 1-45 for Rehearsal Landing with Ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. Proceeded out of Harbor and screened sortie of transports. Formed cruising disposition and departed at 1457.

June 24 Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO en route to Rehearsal Landing area. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

During the morning Rehearsal Landing carried out on Southeast coast of Morotai Island. SAUFLEY acted as screening ship and simulated fire support ship during this time. Upon completion of Rehearsal SAUFLEY directed by Commander Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO POINT FIFTEEN, Commander Screen, to join USS FLUSSER and PC 1134 as screen for LST's returning to staging area. SAUFLEY returned to Morotai Harbor with this group and anchored at 1745.

June 25 Anchored in Morotai Harbor, Morotai, Halmahera Group. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH). Underway during morning to fuel. Moored alongside USS PHILIP at 1037.

June 26 Moored starboard side to USS PHILIP in Morotai Harbor, Morotai, Halmahera Group. (SOPA, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH). Underway at 1217 in accordance with Commander Amphibious Group SIX Attack Order 6-45 to screen sortie of transport units. At 1455 Task Group formed cruising disposition and departed Morotai for Balikpapan, Borneo. During afternoon ships of screen fired AA practice at a towed sleeve.

June 2 En route from Morotai, Halmahera Group, to Balikpapan, Borneo, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

June 28 En route from Morotai, Halmahera Group, to Balikpapan, Borneo, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

June 29 En route from Morotai, Halmahera Group, to Balikpapan, Borneo, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

June 30 En route from Morotai, Halmahera Group, to Balikpapan, Borneo, with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command, Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO, Rear Admiral NOBLE in USS WASATCH).

January 1. En route from Seeadler Harbor, Manus Island to Humboldt Bay, New Guinea. At 0540 entered Humboldt Bay, fueled, and anchored in destroyer anchorage area. In accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY SEVEN POINT NINE's secret dispatch 310130 of December underway from Humboldt Bay at 0936 and proceeded to rendezvous with Task Force SEVENTY NINE.

January 2. En route from Humboldt Bay, New Guinea to rendezvous with Task Force SEVENTY NINE. At O410 contacted Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO. After transferring intelligence material to flagships of Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE, Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE and Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO joined anti-submarine screen of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO. (Officer in Tactical Command Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO - Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE - Vice Admiral WILKINSON in USS MOUNT OLYMPUS).

January 3. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO en route from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE - Vice Admiral WILKINSON in USS MOUNT OLYMPUS) (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO - Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). Several sound contacts were reported and investigated by screening ships during the afternoon, but no positive proof of the presence of enemy submarines.

January 4. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO en route from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE - Vice Admiral WILKINSON in USS MOUNT OLYMPUS), (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO - Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). During the morning anti-aircraft gunnery practice was conducted by the transports between 0930 and 1030. From 1330 to 1430 the transports conducted tactical exercises. Ships of the screen reported two sound contacts during the early afternoon, but no positive proof of the presence of enemy submarines.

January 5. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO en route from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE - Vice Admiral WILKINSON in USS MOUNT OLYMPUS), (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO - Rear Admiral ROYAL in USS ROCKY MOUNT). During the morning the ships of the screen fueled. At 1428 detached from Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO and proceeded to join Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE as directed by verbal orders of Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO.

January 6. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE en route from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE - Rear Admiral KILAND in USS MOUNT MCKINLEY). At 0421 entered Leyte Gulf, then proceeded South through Surigao Straits and into Mindanao Sea. The Combat Air Patrol shot down a Jill inside the formation at 1712. Entered the Sulu Sea around 2030.

January 7. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE en route from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE - Rear Admiral KILAND in USS MOUNT MCKINLEY). During the morning the ships of the screen fueled. The Task Group passed through Cuyo East Pass in the morning entering the China Sea in late afternoon.

January 8. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE en route from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE - Rear Admiral KILAND in USS MOUNT MCKINLEY). At 1630 Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE closed Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT TWO taking position close astern. Task Force SEVENTY NINE was attacked by eight to ten enemy planes (Vals and Zekes) at 1810, Combat Air Patrol shot down four Vals on the port quarter of the formation at approximately 1820. At 1858 observed one suicide plane crash into the port quarter of the USS KITKUN BAY. SAUFLEY opened fire at 1904 on single Val crossing astern. This plane crashed close aboard one of the transports. At 1935 area clear of enemy planes. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 012 of 16 January 1945).

January 9. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE en route from Manus Island to the Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY NINE POINT ONE - Rear Admiral KILAND in USS MOUNT MCKINLEY). This Task Group in company with other groups of the attack force entered Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island prior to sunrise and commenced scheduled attack plan. SAUFLEY lying to screening Task Force SEVENTY NINE transport area. During the day there were several light air attacks, SAUFLEY fired on planes as opportunity permitted during a sunset attack. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 012 of 16 January 1945).

January 10. Lying to screening Task Force SEVENTY NINE transport area, Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island. At sunrise shipping in the gulf was attacked by Japanese planes, SAUFLEY opened fire on various planes as opportunity permitted. At 0720 Val attempted to crash into the SAUFLEY and missed, crashing into the sea approximately fifteen yards on the starboard bow. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 012 of 16 January 1945). During the day screened Task Force SEVENTY NINE transport area, At 1735 screened transports en route from Lingayen transport area to San Fabian transport area.

January 11. Screening to the South of the San Fabian transport area, Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island. During the morning screened USS MOUNT OLYMPUS, USS ROCKY MOUNT, and USS MOUNT MCKINLEY en route from the San Fabian transport area to the Lingayen transport area. At 1000 resumed screening Lingayen transport area. A suspicious small craft attempted to close this ship at 2257, but was evaded and disappeared.

January 12. Screening to the Westward of the Lingayen transport area, Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island. Enemy aircraft attacked shipping at 0800. SAUFLEY fired on enemy planes at 0803 and 0805. No results observed. (See SAUFLEY Action Report serial 012 of 16 January 1945). At 1020 proceeded to San Fabian transport area to fuel as directed by Screen Commander. Fueling interrupted by report of enemy planes in area at 1158. Returned to Lingayen and resumed screening transport area at 1223. In accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY NINE's dispatch 120436 formed up with Task Unit SEVENTY NINE POINT FOURTEEN POINT SIX (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral CONOLLY in USS APPALACHIAN) at 1800 and departed Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island for Leyte Gulf.

January 13. Steaming in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY NINE POINT FOURTEEN POINT SIX en route from Lingayen Gulf, Luzon to Leyte Gulf. (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral CONOLLY in USS APPALACHIAN). At 0820 the formation was attacked by a single Japanese plane which evaded the Combat Air Patrol in the clouds and crashed into the USS ZEILIN. SAUFLEY recovered one survivor from the sea at 0840.

January 14. Steaming in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY NINE POINT FOURTEEN POINT SIX en route from Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island to Leyte Gulf. (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral CONOLLY in USS APPALACHIAN). There were several air alerts during the day, but the formation was never attacked.

January 15. Steaming in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY NINE POINT FOURTEEN POINT SIX en route from Lingayen Gulf, Luzon Island to Leyte Gulf. (Officer in Tactical Command - Rear Admiral CONOLLY in USS APPALACHIAN). During the afternoon the formation entered Leyte Gulf and anchored in the Abuyog Transport area. At 1734 the SAUFLEY anchored approximately one mile East of Abuyog Transport area.

January 16. Anchored one mile Hast of Abuyog transport area Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. In accordance with verbal orders of Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO underway at 1020 and proceeded to San Pedro Bay where SAUFLEY fueled, loaded ammunition, and anchored in vicinity of berth #25 at 1957.

January 17. Anchored in vicinity of berth #25, San Pedro Bay, Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. During the morning SAUFLEY shifted berths to be closer to provision ship. Underway at 1645 as directed by Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO and proceeded out of San Pedro Bay to Abuyog transport area. Anchored one mile East of the transport area at 1827. During air alert at 2040 underway and laid smoke screen to the East of transport. area as directed by Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO. Returned to anchorage at 2133. Area clear of enemy planes.

January 18. Anchored one mile Hast of Abuyog transport area Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. In accordance with Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO dispatch 180500 underway at 1700 to rendezvous with Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE. At 1800 formed Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE composed of Transport Division FORTY ONE, FORTY TWO, TWENTY ONE (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Transport Division FORTY ONE in USS LATIMER) and USS SIGOURNEY, USS PHILIP, USS WALLER and USS SAUFLEY as screen. This Task Group then took departure from Leyte Gulf, Philippine Island for Manus Island and Morotai Island.

January 19. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE en route from Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands to Manus Island and Morotai Island. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Transport Division FORTY ONE in USS LATIMER).

January 20. Steaming in company with ships of Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE en route from Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands to Manus Island and Morotai Island. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Transport Division FORTY ONE in USS LATIMER). At 0205 USS SIGOURNEY and USS SAUFLEY formed screen for Transport Division TWENTY ONE and became Task Unit SEVENTY BIGHT POINT FIVE POINT Two (Officer in Tactical Command Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE in HMAS MANOORA). This unit departed from main group and set course for Morotai Island.

January 21. Steaming in company with ships of Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT FIVE POINT TWO en route from Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands to Morotai Island. (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE in HMAS MANOORA). During the morning SAUFLEY screened to seaward as the transports proceeded to anchorage and then anchored off Southwest shore of Morotai Island at 0918. At 1110 Lieutenant Commander Francis W. SILK reported on board for duty as prospective Commanding Officer. Underway at 1330 to fuel. Returned to anchorage at 1857.
January 22.-24. Anchored off the Southwest shore of Morotai Island. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE in HMAS MANOORA).

January 25. Anchored off the Southwest shore of Morotai Island. (Senior Officer Present Afloat - Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE in HMAS MANOORA). Underway at 0612 as directed by Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE dispatch 242228 of January and took departure from Morotai Island for Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands.

January 26. En route from Morotai Island to Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. Passed through Eastern Surigao Strait at 1425 and entered Leyte Gulf. At 1516 entered San Pedro Bay, Leyte, Philippine Islands, fueled, and anchored in berth #456 at 2006. Reported to Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT for duty in accordance with Commander Transport Division TWENTY ONE dispatch 242228 of January.
January 27. Anchored in berth #456, San Pedro Bay, Leyte, Philippine Islands.
January 28, Anchored in berth #456, San Pedro Bay, Leyte, Philippine Islands.

January 29. Anchored in berth #456, San Pedro Bay, Leyte, Philippine Islands. At 0728 underway in accordance with Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT dispatch 280624 of January and formed Task Unit SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWELVE POINT SIX with CGC INGHAM en route to Luzon, Philippine Islands. (Officer in Tactical Command in CGC INGHAM).

January 30. Steaming en route from Leyte to Luzon, Philippine Islands escorting CGC INGHAM. (Officer in Tactical Command in CGC INGHAM). At 1135 directed by Officer in Tactical Command to proceed to Agutaya Island and search for survivors of downed friendly plane. Arrived at Agutaya Island at 1238 and sighted survivors on beach at 1243. Army rescue craft P493 arrived in vicinity and assumed task of recovering survivors from the beach. At 1330 SAUFLEY departed Agutaya Island to rejoin CGC INGHAM prior dark as directed. Rejoined CGC INGHAM at 1743 West of Mindoro Island.

January 31. Steaming en route from Leyte to Luzon, Philippine Islands escorting CGC INGHAM. (Officer in Tactical Command in CGC INGHAM). At 0800 arrived San Antonio area West coast Luzon where Task Unit dissolved and SAUFLEY reported to Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT THREE for duty in accordance with Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT THREE dispatch 281624, At 1015 departed San Antonio escorting USS GRASP en route to Nasugbu as directed verbally by Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT THREE. Arrived Nasugbu Cove, Luzon, Philippine Islands at 1655 and reported for duty to Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO and relieved USS RUSSELL as directed by Commander Task Force SEVENTY EIGHT dispatch 291247. At night retired to the Westward of Nasugbu in company with CGC SPENCER (Officer in Tactical Command - Commander Task Group SEVENTY EIGHT POINT TWO - Rear Admiral FECHTELER) and USS CONYNGHAM.

source.name: USS SAUFLEY - Rep Of Act During period of 8/16-19/43
USS SAUFLEY - Bombardment of Munda, 7/12/43 with Task Force 19
USS SAUFLEY - Action Report, initial landing on Treasury Is, 10/27/43
USS SAUFLEY - A/S Act Rep, 9/15/43, Occup Of Vella Lavella
USS SAUFLEY - AA Act Rep, 11/17/43, Empress Augusta Bay Area

item.description:
0000-0400 Steaming in company with Task Force number NINETEEN on course 173(T), 173(PGC), 159(PSC). Standard speed 15 knots, steaming at full speed, 22 knots. Keeping station #3 in screen with cruisers in cruising formation #2. Boilers #2 and #3 in use.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0530 Crew at general quarters. 0602 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 0612 Secured from general quarters. Sighted USS SABINE and USS CONWAY bearing 192(T), distance 11 miles. 0630 Ceased zig- zagging resumed base course, commenced making preparations for fueling. 0638 Changed speed to 17 knots (173RPM). 0649 Changed course to 130(T), 130(PSG), 115(PSC). 0653 Took station #5 in fueling formation (form 2). 0752 Commenced steering various courses and speeds making approach to fuel at sea from starboard of USS SABINE.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0818 Commenced fueling on course 130(T), (PGC), 117(PSC), speed 9 knots. 0905 Completed fueling, received 71,315 gallons. Changed speed to 20 knots. 0922 Steaming on various courses and speeds to close the USS RENSHAW. 0933 Delivered sea mail to USS RENSHAW on course 130(T), (PGC), 117(PSC). Speed 13 knots. 0943 Commenced patrolling on station in fueling unit screen. Speed 12 knots.
1200-1600 Patrolling as before. 1538 Completed screening of fueling unit, joining USS DENVER, USS CLEVELAND, and USS RENSHAW in screening position 45 on port bow of the leading cruiser 4500 yards distance, base course 270(T), 270(PGC), 261(PSC), speed 20 knots.
1600-2000 Steaming as before.
2000-2400 Steaming as before.

0000-0400 Steaming in company with U.S.S. CLEVELAND and U.S.S. RENSHAW on base course 270(T), (PGC), 262(PSC), speed 20 knots. Boilers #2 and #3 with superheaters in use.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0552 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 0554 Went to general quarters. 0635 Secured from general quarters.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0822 Changed base course to 275(T), 275(PGC), 270(PSC). 1030 Commenced scheduled exercise; firing on simulated periscope. 1130 Ceased present exercise. Expended 6 rounds 5"/38 Cal ammunition. Left screening station to deliver mail to ships of own task group. Steaming on various courses to deliver official mail.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1222 Exercise completed resumed station in screen. 1235 Crew at general quarters. 1238 Sighted U.S.S. NORTH CAROLINA, U.S.S. STANLEY, U.S.S. DYSON, U.S.S. CLAXTON, bearing 038(T), distance 12 miles. 1308 Secured from general quarters. Commenced passing official mail to vessels joining formation. 1424 Exercise completed, resumed station in screen, 70 on starboard bow of guild, range 6000 yards. Steadied as course 270(T), 270(PSG), 265(PSC), speed 18 knots (195 RPM). 1430 Commenced exercise #13, surprise burst. 1500 Exercise completed, expended seven rounds, 5"/38 cal ammunition. 1525 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12.
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1657 Changed base course to 090(T), (PGC), 079(PSC). Speed 17 knots. 1700 Ceased zigzagging. 1732 Commenced zigzagging on plan 12. 1930 Ceased zigzagging.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2000 Changed base course to 135(T), 135(PGC), 121(PSC). 2200 Changed base course to 090(T), 090(PGC), 081(PSC).

0000-0400 Steaming in company with USS NORTH CAROLINA, USS DENVER, USS CLEVELAND, USS RENSHAW, USS CLAXTON, USS DYSON and USS STANLY on course 090(T), 090(PGC), 081(PSC). Standard speed 15 knots, steaming at 17 knots. Boilers #2 and #3 in use. 0400 Changed course to 135(T), 135(PGC), 124(PSC).
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0555 Crew at general quarters. 0605 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 0657 Ceased zigzagging resumed base course. 0701 Changed course to 070(T), 070(PGC), 079(PSC). 0715 Changed course to 270(T), 270(PSG), 262(PSC).
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0822 Ceased zigzagging. 0839 Changed base course to 315(T), (PGC), 313(PSC). 0854 Commenced zigzagging on plan #10. 0900 Commenced scheduled exercise #13. 0946 Ceased present exercise. Expended 6 rounds 5"/38 Cal. AA ammunition. 0959 Ceased zigzagging. 1000 Commenced exercising on turn signals. 1100 Resumed base course. 1110 Commenced zigzagging on plan #10.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1245 Ceased zigzagging - commenced taking station 1200 yards abeam of USS RENSHAW for next exercise. 1300 Commenced radar calibration exercise. 1409 Ceased present exercises - resumed normal screening position. 1437 Commenced taking station 45 on starboard bow of USS DENVER for next exercise. 1539 Ceased present exercises - resumed normal screening formation. 1544 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 1550 Ceased zigzagging. 1557 Changed base course to 225(T), 225(PGC), 214(PSC).
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1645 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 1910 Commenced scheduled exercise; machine gun firing on float lights. Left screening station to assume station for exercise.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2057 Exercise completed resume base course and speed. 2200 Changed course to 180(T), 180(PGC), 166 1/2(PSC). 2300 Changed course to 135(T), 135(PSG), 122(PSC). 2230 Changed course to 090(T), 090(PSG), 079(PSC). 2400 Changed course to 045(T), 045(PSG), 042(PSC).

0000-0400 Steaming in company with U.S.S. NORTH CAROLINA, USS CLEVELAND, USS DENVER, USS RENSHAW, USS STANLEY, USS CLAXTON, and USS DYSON, on base course 090(T), (PGC), 085(PSC), speed 17 knots. Boilers 72 and 73 in use. 0000 Changed base course to 045(T), (PSG), 037(PSC).
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0400 Changed course to 000(T), 000(PGC), 355(PSC). 0550 went to general quarters - commenced zigzagging according to plan #10. 0640 Ceased zigzagging. 0643 Changed base course to 180(T), 180(PGC), 174(PSC). 0714 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 0729 Ceased zigzagging. 0732 Changed base course to 135(T), 135(PGC), 122(PSC). 0750 Changed base course to 110(T), 110(PGC), 098(PSC). 0753 Changed speed to 9 knots.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0800 Commenced fueling destroyers singly from U.S.S. NORTH CAROLINA. Commenced patrolling screening station.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1415 Left screening formation, commenced taking fueling station. 1415 On station receiving fuel starboard side, from port side U.S.S. CLEVELAND. Steadied on base course 110(T), 110(PSG), 098(PSC). Speed 9 knots (86 RPM).
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1629 Completed fueling. Received 67,051 gallons. 1652 Took screening station #4. Patrolling at 12 knots. 1835 Changed base course to 290(T), (PGC), 283(PSC), speed 17 knots. 1846 Commenced zigzagging on plan #10. 1930 Ceased zigzagging.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2000 Changed base course to 245(T), 245(PGC), 236(PSC).

0000-0400 Steaming in company with USS NORTH CAROLINA, USS DENVER, USS CLEVELAND, USS RENSHAW, USS DYSON, USS CLAXTON, and USS STANLY on course 245(T), 245(PGC), 236(PSC). Standard speed 15 knots, steaming at 17 knots. Boiler #2 and #3 in use. 0000 Changed course to 155(T), 155(PGC), 148(PSC). 0100 changed course to 110(T), 110(PGC), 098(PSC). 0300 changed course to 090(T), 090(PGC), 079(PSC). 0345 Steadied on course 097(T), 097(PGC), 086(PSC), increased speed to 25 knots to take station for tracking exercise.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0554 Crew at general quarters. 0605 Changed speed to 16 knots (155 RPM). Changed course to 310(T), 310(PGC), 306(PSC). 0614 Changed course to 210(T), 210(PGC), 204(PSC). 0628 Changed course to 260(T), 260(PGC), 252(PSC). 0657 Rejoined formation, took screening station #5. 0704 changed course to 270(T), 270(PSG), 266(PSC). 0734 Commenced exercise #16, Radar gun calibration practice. Changed course to take station 30 on starboard bow of USS CLEVELAND. 0759 Steadied on base course.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. Screening cruisers acting as target for offset practice. 0952 Fired main battery offset practice. Expended 14 rounds 5"/38 Cal. 1045 Resumed station in formation screen. 1057 Changed base course to 090(T), (PGC), 082(PSC). Changed speed of formation to 12 knots. 1100 Commenced delivery of mail to USS RENSHAW, USS CLEVELAND, USS NORTH CAROLINA, and USS DENVER.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1217 Completed delivery of mail - resuming normal screening station. 1258 Commenced offset gun practice. 1422 Completed exercise having expended 6 rounds of 5"/38 Cal AA common - no casualties. 1453 Commenced zig- zagging in accordance with plan #12. 1212 Changed base course to 270(T), 270(PGC), 263(PSC). 1429 Changed base course to 090(T), 090(PGC), 081(PSC). 1510 Ceased zigzagging. 1526 On various courses and speeds joining with USS MONTPELIER, USS COLUMBIA, USS WALLER, USS PRINGLE, and USS PHILIP, USS NORTH CAROLINA, USS CLAXTON, USS DYSON, and USS STANLY detached from task group. 1539 Changed base course 352(T), 352(PGC), 349(PSC). 1550 Lit off boilers #1 and #4.
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1610 Cut boilers #1 and #4 in on main steam line. 1634 Changed course to 355(T), 355(PGC), 352(PSC). 1700 Increased speed to 29 knots.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2152 Changed course to 056(T), 056(PSG), 048(PSC). 2214 Commenced taking station #2 in cast formation #1. Changed speed to 22 knots (222 RPM). 2215 Secured boiler #1. 2225 Secured boiler #4.

0000-0400 Steaming in company with Task Force number NINETEEN on base 056(T), (PGC), 051 (PSC), speed 22 knots. Boilers #2 and #3 in use.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0544 Went to general quarters. 0545 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 0638 Ceased zigzagging. 0657 Resumed zigzagging. O746 Ceased zigzagging. 0741 Changed speed to 25 knots. 0751 Changed speed to 26 knots. 0756 Changed speed to 27 knots. 0750 Lit boilers 1 & 4. 0800 Cut boiler 1 & 4 in on main steam line.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0908 Increased speed to 29 knots. 1004 Changed course to 040(T), 040(PGC), 033(PSC). 1038 Changed course to 315(T), 315(PGC), 312(PSC). 1155 Changed course to 285(T), 285(PGC), 280(PSC).
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1225 Formed column, passing through Sealark Channel, Steering various courses and making various speeds. 1302 Steering various courses to regain position in screen. Secured #1 superheater. Steadied on 260(T), 260(PSG), 253(PSC), speed 15 knots (149 RPM) 1320 Changed course to 225(T), 225(PSG), 223(PSC). 1325 Changed course to 180(T), 180(PSG), 180(PSC). Secured boilers #1 and #4. Commenced patrolling between Koli Point and Lunga Point. Speed 10 knots (96 RPM). 1515 Proceeding to Tulagi Harbor to fuel, course 343(T), 343(PSG), 338(PSC), speed 25 knots (225 RPM). 1550 Commenced making preparations for entering harbor, steering various course and speeds. Captain at conn, navigator on bridge, standard speed 15 knots (146 RPM).
1600-2000 Steaming as before, 1629 Anchored in Tulagi Harbor in 22 fathoms of water with 30 fathoms of chain to port anchor. 1635 Underway. 1645 Moored starboard side to oil barge. 1653 Commenced receiving fuel. Draft aft 13'0" forward 11'10". 1721 Completed fueling. Draft forward 11'1", aft 13'11". Received 20,000 gallons. Commenced making preparations to get underway. 1725 Underway. Steaming on various courses and speeds to clear harbor. 1740 Set course 260(T), (PGC), 256(PSC), speed 25 knots. 1748 Boilers #1 and #4 with superheaters cut in on main line. 1750 Changed speed to 30 knots. 1803 Changed speed to 25 knots. Changed course to 180(T), to take station 4 in task Force NINETEEN screen. 1817 Changed speed to 27 knots. 1830 Formation deployed on base course 302(T), (PGC), 299(PSC). Speed 29 knots.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2300 Went to general quarters.

0000-0400 Steaming in company with Task Force number NINETEEN on course 302(T), 302(PGC), 269(PSC). Standard speed 15 knots, steaming at flank speed 27 knots. Task Force deployed in battle formation. Condition of readiness I, material condition afirm set. Boilers #1, 2, 3, 4 in use. 0119 Changed course to 122(T), 122(PGC), 108(PSC), by ships turn movement. 0240 Changed course to 119(T), 119(PGC), 110(PSC). 0330 Set condition of readiness II, material condition baker.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0600 Crew at General Quarters, taking station #4 in jig formation #1. 0642 Secured from General Quarters. 0650 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 0707 Changed speed to 22 knots (222 RPM). 0733 Ceased zigzagging resumed base course. 0740 Changed speed to 20 knots (201 RPM). 0745 Commenced steering various courses and speeds taking station #2 in Cast formation, #1.
0800-1200 Steaming on base course 110(T), (PGC), 099(PSC), speed 20 knots, passing south of Savo Island in cruising formation #1. 0826 Commenced zigzagging on plan 10. 0830 Secured boilers #1 and #4. 0852 Ceased zigzagging. 0853 Changed course to 060(T), (PSC), 052(PSC). Screening entry of USS MONTPELIER and USS COLUMBIA into Purvis Bay. 0924 Steaming various courses and speeds entering Tulagi, Harbor. 1015 Moored starboard side to oil barge. 1019 Commenced fueling; Draft forward 10'10" aft 13'6". 1125 Commenced making preparations for getting underway. 1149 Completed fueling; Draft forward 12'0", aft 13'0". Received 88,342 gallons. 1153 Underway steaming various courses and speeds, clearing Tulagi, Harbor, standing into Purvis Bay.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1207 Passed through submarine nets Tulagi, Harbor. 1206 on various courses and speeds conforming to approaches to Purvis Bay. 1227 Pass through inner submarine net Purvis Bay. 1228 On various courses and speeds standing up Port Purvis to anchorage. 1245 Anchored in berth 16 Port Purvis in 22 fathoms of water with 60 fathoms of chain on deck to the port anchor on the following bearings. Point Fox 177 3/4(T), 177 3/4 (PGC), 169 (PSC). Point How 104 1/2(T), 104 1/2(PGC), 097(PSC). Point Baker 269(T), 269(PGC), 261(PSC). Point Dog 240 1/2(T), 240 1/2(PGC), 232(PSC). 1525 Commenced preparations for getting underway.
1600-2000 Anchored as before. 1601 Underway in accordance with Commander Third Fleet Fleets 070007 of July in company with Task Force NINETEEN. Standing out of harbor on various courses conforming to channel. 1608 Lit off boilers #1 and #4. 1614 Cut boilers #1 and #4 in on main steam line. 1617 Passed through outer submarine nets. Commenced patrolling off entrance Port Purvis. 1712 Cruisers standing out of Port Purvis. Base course 270(T), 270(PGC), 265(PSC), speed 20 knots. 1720 took station #5 in anti-submarine screen. Changed course to 299(T), 299(PGC), 294(PSC). 1730 Increased speed to 25 knots. 1737 increased speed to 26 knots. 1800 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 1803 Reduced speed to 25 knots. 1830 Ceased zigzagging. 1845 Deployed to battle formation.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2116 Went to general quarters.

0000-0400 Steaming in company with Task Force NINETEEN on base course 299(T), 299(PGC), 295(PSC). Standard speed 15 knots, steaming at flank speed 25 knots. Condition of readiness I set, material condition afirm set. Boiler #1, #2; #3, #4 in use. Task Force deployed in battle formation. 0137 Changed course to 119(T), 119(PGC), 106(PSC).
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0510 Detached from formation to investigate surface contact. 0515 Went to general quarters. 0530 Sighted enemy submarine. On various courses and speeds making attack. 0534 Commenced firing 5" battery, machine guns and torpedo battery. 0536 Ceased firing, sub having submerged, 42 rounds of 5"/38 Cal common, 3O rounds of 40MM and two torpedoes expended - no casualties. 0540 Made sound contact — on various courses, speed 17 making run on submarine. 0554 Fired 9 charge shallow pattern, no visible results. 0600 Patrolling on various courses and speeds. 0613 Made sound contact - making run on submarine. 0617 Fired nine charge medium pattern - no visible results. 0624 Resumed patrolling on various courses, speed 15 knots, searching for submarine.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0825 Secured boiler #1. 0825 Secured boiler #4.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1340 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10.
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1806 Relieved by U.S.S. PHILIP. Set course 122(T), (PGC), 117(PSC). Speed 28 knots, for Tulagi Harbor.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2008 Changed base course to 110(T), 110(PGC), 095(PSC). 2028 Changed speed to 25 knots. 2045 Changed speed to 20 knots. 2048 On various courses and speeds conforming to approaches to Tulagi Harbor. 2141 Pass through submarine net. 2145 On various courses and speeds standing up Tulagi Harbor, 2155 Anchored in berth #4, Tulagi Harbor with 75 fathoms of chain to the port anchor in 35 fathoms of water on the following bearings, Small Inlet 009 1/2(T), 009 1/2PGC), 359(PSC). Left Tangent Gavutu 080 1/2(T), 080 1/2(PGC), O71(PSC). ACTION REPORT OF ATTACK ON JAPANESE SUBMARINE 8 July 1943

1. During the approach, after being directed to investigate, the ship went to General Quarters and preparations were made for torpedo, gun and depth charge attack. Torpedoes were left at basic depth setting of ten (10) feet and medium speed. Depth charges were set for a nine charge medium pattern (two hundred (200) feet). Main battery director was put on target and commenced tracking immediately. Control was directed to be prepared to illuminate with star shells from one gun when fire was opened. Both SG and FD radars had good contacts. Some uncertainty arose as to the nature of the target however because of the low speed and apparent erratic courses until about 0526.

2. In addition, the FD radar reported two targets in line and about one thousand (1000) yards apart. The near target disappeared from the FD screen, however, at about five thousand (5000) yards and from then on both plot and CIC agreed on target course and speed. The early stages of the CIC plot resembled that of a rain squall however. This may have been due to inaccurate ranges and bearings at the extreme ranges first obtained for this type of target, or it may have been due to the submarine's lying to, or possibly to the presence of two or more targets.

3. When the range was about four thousand (4000) yards the target was seen directly ahead and indistinctly in binoculars from the bridge. Since target speed was still low, the decision was made to stand on before opening fire in case the submarine was slow to diving and a ramming attack became possible. The target quickly became more distinct, probably due to the beginning of dawn, and at two thousand five hundred (2500) yards was clearly visible. At that time (0533) the target was seen to be broadside on to us, still making very low speed, and high out of the water. It appeared similar to the I-1 class except that no deck guns were observed. His length was estimated as about three hundred (300) feet.

4. At that time it was believed that the submarine could not possibly fail to see us and therefore course was altered about 40 to the right and Main Battery and Torpedo Party told to stand by. As soon as the after guns would bear orders were given to fire 5” and also a salvo of three (3) torpedoes. Then the range had closed to about two thousand (2000) yards commenced firing with 20 and 40mm machine guns. Eight (8) salvos of 5" were fired and seven (7) starshells. The Commanding Officer gave "Cease fire torpedo battery" after the Torpedo Officer ordered “Fire three”. The torpedoman on the ready switches was slow, however, and the third torpedo did not get off on the Torpedo Officer's command. the the torpedoman heard the Commanding Officer's "Cease fire" he failed to close his switch for the third torpedo. Right after that the submarine submerged at a range of about twelve hundred (1200) yards, and about abeam. Gunfire was ceased and the rudder was then put hard left in an attempt to reach a position for dropping depth charges. The close range and shock of gunfire as well as the 5" splashes prevented SG radar and CIC party from getting a clear radar plot and the high speed prevented getting any sound plot. After getting the rudder over, however, the speed was reduced to eighteen (18) knots and echo ranging begun.

5. The 5" salvos were reported to straddle by the spotter although several were observed short from the bridge. It was afterwards found the director pointer had been using his sight on the horizon until fire was opened but that the splashes prevented him from seeing clearly after that and it is believed that his pointing was erratic. Hereafter full reliance will be placed on the stable element for night firing and laying by telescope will not be attempted unless stable element fails.

6. It is believed that the torpedoes probably missed due to their shallow setting and the fact that the submarine probably got beneath them just as they crossed the line. All other factors in the setup were rechecked immediately after firing and no errors were found. It is now believed that one tube mount should be put on twenty-five (25) feed basic depth setting and the other left on a shallow for future attacks of this type. Ordinarily on runs "Up the slot" from Guadalcanal it is believed that the most likely targets are destroyers and light transports and accordingly shallow depth settings are required.

7. After echo ranging was begun the target was finally picked up by sound gear on bearing 225 range one thousand (1000) yards. The ship was brought right to the attack course, continuing the speed eighteen (18) knots. On reaching that course it was found that the submarine had reversed course to give us a stern chase. Range rate was about ten (10) knots. The reversal of submarine course made it difficult to set a lead angle but it is believed that a correct approach was finally made because a large boil was observed in the water about fifty (50) feet off the starboard bow just before the depth charges were dropped. The firing was done from the recorder using a five (5) second extra delay. The depth charge pattern extended about one hundred (100) yards beyond the "boil" along the track.

8. After returning for a second attack, speed was reduced to fifteen (15) knots and contact was finally made at 0613 and a new run begun. In this case the echoes were weaker than the first one and could not conclusively be said to be a submarine.

9. An attack was made however, as shown on the track chart and a second nine (9) charge pattern dropped. One good echo was obtained dead aft at five hundred (500) yards about one minute after the last charge was dropped. Thereafter no more contacts could be obtained. The area was searched for twelve (12) hours by this ship as shown on the track chart. At that time the SAUFLEY was relieved by the U.S.S. PHILIP and search continued for about seven (7) hours additional.

10. In view of the fact that the USS PHILIP also had SG Radar and made no contacts after dark it is believed that the submarine was hit by the first depth charge pattern and sunk. If it had been undamaged it is believed that it would have surfaced after dark and attempted to escape. In that case it is believed that it would been picked up by the PHILIP's SG radar.

11. In future attacks of this sort a high speed direct approach will be made. If no unusual motion of target is observed a pattern of three (3) torpedoes will be fired using curved fire ahead and a twenty-five (25) foot depth setting with magnetic exploder inoperative. This permits a direct ramming approach in case the submarine does not submerge in time. It is believed that gunfire is relatively ineffective at the longer ranges of 5000 - 6000 yards and at short ranges the turn to bring all guns to bear hampers a ramming approach. In any event gunfire gives a very positive warning of the destroyer's presence and the submarine is sure to dive immediately if not hit on one of the early salvos.

12. In this case it is not believed that the Japanese listening gear was very effective since no action was taken by the submarine until a range of twenty-five hundred (2500) yards Was reached and gunfire begun. It should be noted that the SAUFLEY did not echo range until after the submarine submerged.

Action Report: Chronological record of events.
0515 SAUFLEY received orders from Commander Destroyer Squadron TWENTY TWO to investigate and report on surface radar contact reported by the USS CLEVELAND at 0510.
0516 Changed course to 056 T, SAUFLEY contact bearing, range 18000 yards. SAUFLEY speed 27 knots.
0519 CIC commenced tracking, range 15000 yards.
0521 CIC reported target course 130, slow moving target, probably submarine.
0523 CIC reported target changing course to the right, course 240, speed 7 knots.
0523 Commenced steering directly toward target.
0525 CIC reported target changing course to the left.
0527 CIC reported target on course 140 at speed of 5 knots.
0533 Changed course to the right to 100 T and commenced firing with main battery, range about 2300 yards bearing 062 from CIC Plot.
0534 Commenced firing with 20mm and 40mm guns, fired two torpedoes, range about 1600 bearing 055 from CIC Plot. SG radar lost contact.
0535 Submarine submerging.
0536 Ceased firing, changed course to the left and steadied on course 055.
0540 Slowed to 18 knots.
0544 Changed course to about 170 to pick up sound contact.
0548 Picked up sound contact bearing 225 T, range 1000 yards. CIC commenced tracking.

0550 Changed course to overtake submarine - stern chase.
0552 CIC reported submarine course 280 T.
0555 Control reported large "boil" in water about 50 feet on starboard bow. Also observed from bridge. First depth charges dropped about 15 seconds afterward. Last charge of pattern about 100 yards beyond "boil".
0555 Dropped first 9 charge pattern Latitude 08-23-45 S. Longitude 158-53-00 E.
0600 Slowed to 15 knots and changed course to 090 to regain contact.
0613 Picked up second contact bearing 200, range 1400 yards. Weak echoes.
0613 Changed course to contact bearing CIC. Unable to plot course of due to fact echoes were weak and not consistent.
0617 Dropped second 9 charge pattern Latitude 08-25-50, Longitude 158-55-00.
0619 One definite echo obtained right astern, distant 500 yards. No other echoes could be obtained however.
0623 Reversed course in attempt to regain contact.
0634 Commenced searching area, unable to regain contact.

0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0400 Commenced firing at planes. 0404 Ceased firing having expended 109 rounds of 5"/38 Cal AA Common ammunition. 0414 Changed course to 120(T), 120(PGC), 116(PSC), following astern of the USS WALLER, speed 18 knots. 0655 On various courses and speeds maneuvering to take anti-aircraft screening station on APD's. 0748 Leaving APD's on various courses and speeds, taking station astern of USS WALLER - base course 120(T), 120(PGC), 116(PSC), speed 30 knots.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 1009 Changed speed to 25 knots. 1025 Changed speed to 20 knots. 1028 Secured boilers #1 and #4. 1058 Made preparations for entering port. 1101 Changed speed to 15 knots. Steering various courses conforming to channel entering Port Purvis. 1112 Entered Purvis Bay. 1131 Steering various courses leaving Purvis Bay. 1154 Entered Tulagi Harbor. Made preparations to moor port side to USS PRINGLE.
1200-1600 Moored as before. 1238 Commenced receiving fuel on port side from oil barge. Draft forward 10'9", draft aft 13'1". 1515 Commenced making preparations force getting underway. 1518 Fueling completed, received 73,225 gallons. Draft forward 12'0", draft aft 14'11". 1519 Underway, Captain at conn, executive officer on bridge, proceeding to berth #17. 1555 Anchored in berth #17, Tulagi Harbor, 22 fathoms of water, 60 fathoms of chain to port anchor.
1600-2000 Anchored as before. 1850 commenced making preparations for getting underway. 1928 Underway in accordance with Commander THIRD Fleets, 180512 of July. En route Espiritu Santos screening USS TRYON.
2000-2400 Steaming as before, base course 178(T), 178(PGC), 175(PSC). 2032 Changed base course 090(T), 090(PGC), 087 1/2(PSC). 2050 Changed speed to 18 1/2 knots. 2130 Changed course to 102(T), 102(PGC), 096 1/2(PSC). 2313 Changed course to 121 1/2(T), 121 1/2(PGC), 114(PSC). 2327 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #11.

0000-0400 Steaming on base course 121 1/2(T), 121 1/2(PGC), 114(PSC), escorting USS TRYON, en route Espiritu Santo. Standard speed 15 knots, steaming at 18 1/2 knots. Zigzagging in accordance with plan #11. Boiler #1 and #4 in use. 0127 Changed base course to 098(T), 098(PGC), 092(PSC). 0327 Changed base course to 119(T), 119(PGC), 113(PSC).
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0927 Called crew to general quarters. 0609 Secured from general quarters, set condition II, material condition baker.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 1057 Changed course to 193(T), 192(PGC), 186 1/2 (PSC). 0800 Position: Latitude 10-31-30 S, Longitude 163-15-00 E.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1200 Position: Latitude 11-10-20 S, Longitude 163-57-30 E.
1600-2000 Steaming as before.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2000 Position: 13-36-00 S., 163-25-15 E.

0000-0400 En route Tulagi to Espiritu Santo escorting USS TRYON on base course 193(T), 192(PGC), 186 1/2 (PSC). Speed 18.5 knots zigzagging in accordance with plan #11. Boilers #1 and #4 in use. Gyro error 1 E. 0300 Detached from USS TRYON. Change course to 090(T), 089(PGC), 081(PSC). Changed speed to 27 knots. Ceased zigzagging.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0527 Went to general quarters. 0605 Secured from general quarters.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0800 Position: Latitude 15-35-00 S., Longitude 165-18-00 E. 0818 Changed course to 095(T), 094 1/2(PGC), 085(PSC). 0923 Sighted Espiritu Santo Island bearing 070(T), distance 50 miles. 1142 Changed course to 100(T), 100(PGC), 091(PSC).
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1207 Changed course to 090(T), 089(PGC), 082(PSC). 1222 Passed Malo Point abeam to port. 1230 Changed course to 000(T), 359(PSG), 347(PSC). changed speed to 25 knots (256 RPM). 1246 Changed course to 335(T), 334(PSG), 329(PSC). 1303 Commenced making preparations for entering port. Captain at conn, executive officer on bridge, steering various courses conforming with channel. Standard speed 15 knots (146 RPM). 1351 Moored starboard side to port of S.S. WESTERN SUN, berth #35, Segond Channel, Espiritu Santo, New Hebrides Island. 1421 Commenced fueling, draft forward 10'11", draft aft 13'11". 1545 completed fueling, received 51,677 gallons, draft forward 12'0", draft aft 14'1".
1600-2000 Moored as before. 1635 Making preparations to get underway. 1703 underway for anchorage. Captain at the conn, executive officer and navigator on the bridge, on various courses and speeds conforming to the channel. 1739 Anchored in berth #25, Second Channel, Espiritu Santo in 28 fathoms of water with 75 fathoms of chain to the port anchor on the following bearing, C 018 1/2(T), 018(PGC), 014(PSC) D 102 3/4(T), 102 1/4 (PGC), 098 1/4(PSC) - G 290 1/2(T), 290(PGC), 286(PSC). Secured fires under boiler #1, boiler 34 in use for auxiliary purposes.
2000-2400 Anchored as before. 2335 Underway in accordance with Commander THIRD Fleet's dispatch [] June, Captain at the conn, executive officer and navigator on the bridge on various courses and speeds conforming to the channel standing out Espiritu Harbor. 2350 Passed through submarine nets.

0000-0400 Steaming on various courses conforming to channel en route from Espiritu Santo Island. Standard speed 15 knots, steaming at full speed, 20 knots. Boilers #1, #2, #3, #4 in use. 0011 Increased speed to 25 knots. 0015 Changed speed to 30 knots. 0025 Steadied on course 180(T), (PGC), 171(PSC). 0400 Changed course to 270(T), (PGC), 258(PSC). Entering swept channel through Bougainville Straits. 0049 Increased speed to 32 knots. 0059 Changed course to 282(T), (PGC), 268(PSC). Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0450 Contacted H.M.A.S. HOBART, U.S.S. REDFORD, and U.S.S. NICOLAS, bearing 283(T), distance 11 miles. 0511 Secured boilers #2 and #3. Changed speed to 25 knots (256 RPM). 0518 Took screening station #2. Changed speed to 20 knots (201 RPM). Patrolling on station. Changed course to 105(T), 104(PSG), 095(PSC). 0527 Crew called to general quarters. 0614 Secured from general quarters, set condition II material condition baker. 0723 Changed course to 102(T), 101(PSG), 094(PSC).
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 1126 Changed base course to 099(T), (PGC), 090(PSC). 0800 Position: Latitude 15-29-00 S., Longitude 165-26-30 E.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1259 changed course to 103(T), 102 1/2(PSG), 093 1/2(PSC). 1359 Changed course to 106(T), 105 1/2(PGC), 099 1/2(PSC). 1402 USS TREVOR joined formation. 1405 USS TREVOR detached from formation. 1439 Detached from formation in accordance with Commander THIRD Fleet's 202350 June. Changed base course to 289(T), 288 1/2(PGC), 276 1/2(PSC). Changed speed to 20 knots. 1449 Changed speed to 25 knots. 1454 Changed speed to 27 knots. 1508 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 1521 Changed speed to 28 knots. 1532 Changed base course to 285(T), 284 1/2(PGC), 271 1/2(PSC). 1200 Position: Latitude 16-00-00 S., Longitude 163-00-00 E.
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1603 Changed base course to 281(T), 281(PGC), 269(PSC).
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2000 Position: Latitude 15-03-00 S., 164-12-00 E. 2100 Changed course to 291(T), 290(PSG), 279(PSC).

0000-0400 En route from Espiritu Santo to rendezvous with Task Unit THIRTY SIX POINT TWO, Base course 291(T), (PGC), 279(PSC). speed 28 knots. Boilers #1 and #4 in use. Zigzagging on modified plan #10.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0547 went to general quarters. 0640 Secured from general quarters. 0731 Changed base course to 325(T), 324 1/2(PGC), 315(PSC). 0745 On various courses and speeds rejoining Task Unit THIRTY SIX POINT TWO.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0810 Patrolled ahead of formation on various courses during fueling operation. Base course 160(T), (PGC), 152(PSC). speed 9 knots. 0915 Commenced fueling at sea from port side of USS COLUMBIA. 1043 Completed fueling, resumed patrolling ahead of formation. Received 67,806 gallons of fuel oil. 0800 Position Latitude 13-07-00 E., Longitude 159-02-00 E.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1200 Position: Latitude 12-37-30 S., Longitude 159-20-40 E. 1215 Changed course to 350(T), 350(PGC), 338 1/2(PSC), changed speed to 20 knots (201 RPM). 1237 Changed speed to 25 knots (256 RPM). Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 1405 Fires lighted under boiler #3. 1420 Fires lighted under boiler #2. 1435 Cut in boiler #2 on main steam line. 1440 cut in boiler #3 on main steam line. 1503 Ceased zigzagging, resumed base course. 1507 Changed course to 145(T), 145(PGC), 139(PSC). Changed speed to 10 knots (96 RPM). Cruisers conducting plan recovery operation. 1525 Operation completed, changed speed to 19 knots(190 RPM). 1531 changed course to 325(T), 325(PSG), 314(PSC). 1541 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10.
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1600 Changed base course to 145(T), (PGC), 139(PSC). 1623 Commenced zigzagging on plan #12. 1637 Secured boilers #2 and #3. 1731 Changed speed to 17 knots, changed course to 065 for aircraft recovery. 1737 Changed base course to 100(T), (PGC), 092 1/2(PSC). Shifted station to 6000 yard circle.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2300 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 2308 Ceased zigzagging. 2310 Detached from Task Group THIRTY SIX POINT TWO, proceeding in company with USS DENVER, USS COLUMBIA, USS RENSHAW in accordance with Commander THIRD FLEET's dispatch 221015 - base course 112(T), 112(PGC), 102(PSC). 2335 Changed speed to 26 knots. 2337 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 2000 Position: Latitude 13-20-00 E., Longitude 160-00-00.

0000-0400 Steaming in company with USS DENVER, USS CLEVELAND, USS RENSHAW, en route to Espiritu Santo Island on base course 112(T), (PGC), 105(PSC). Standard speed 15 knots, steaming at flank speed 26 knots, zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. Boilers #1 and #4 in use.
0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0532 Crew called to general quarters. 0612 Secured from general quarters, set condition II, material condition baker. 0750 Fires lighted under boilers #2 and #3.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0800 Boiler #2 cut in on main line. 0812 Boiler 33 cut in on main line. 0853 Changed speed to 31 knots. 0900 commenced exercise #13, surprise burst practice. 0728 Ceased present exercises. Expended 6 rounds 5"/38 Cal AA Common. 1105 sighted Espiritu Santo bearing 095(T).
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1241 commenced firing machine guns at sleeve in accordance with exercise #5 set forth on Task Force NINETEEN's Training Instructions. 1324 Ceased zigzagging. 1335 Changed base course to 090(T), 090(PGC), 079(PSC). 1357 commenced zigzagging. 1359 Forming in column astern of USS RENSHAW - proceeding through Bougainville Strait. 1415 Secured fires under Boiler #2. 1425 Secured fires under boiler #3. 1438 on various courses, speed 25 knots approaching entrance to Espiritu Harbor. 1456 resumed zigzagging on base course 000(T), 000(PGC), 350(PSC). 1512 Ceased zigzagging. 1535 Patrolling off harbor entrance during entry of cruisers. 1200 Position: latitude 15-33-00 S., 166-08-00 E.
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1601 Maneuvering on various courses and at various speeds approaching Segond Channel. 1620 Entering Segond Channel. 1658 Moored to port side SS WESTERN SUN. 106 Commenced fueling - draft forward 11'11", aft 13'10". 1815 Completed fueling - having received 56770 gallons fuel oil, draft forward 12'6", draft aft 14'1". 1820 underway maneuvering on various courses and speeds to new berth. 1910 Moored to starboard side of USS RENSHAW (DD499), berth #24, Segond Channel, Espiritu Santo. On two hours notice.
2000-2400 Moored as before.

Speed 20 knots. 0857 Changed course to 180(T), (PGC), 171(PSC). 0930 Changed base course to 270(T), 270(PGC), 263(PSC) to pass through swept channel, Bougainville Straits. 1026 Cleared swept channel, commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #38. 1130 Changed base course to 290(T), (PGC), 282(PSC).
1200-1600 Steaming as before. Position at 1200, Longitude 166-42-30 E., Latitude 15-46-20 S. 1228 Ceased zigzagging, resumed base course. 1230 Changed speed to 18 knots (179 RPM). 1240 Changed speed to 20 knots (201 RPM). 1241 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #38.
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1646 Ceased zigzagging. 1650 Changed base course to 320(T), (PGC), 312 1/2(PSC). 1705 Commenced zigzagging on plan #38. 1840 Ceased zigzagging. 1845 Changed base course to 287(T), (PGC), 277 1/2(PSC).

0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0400 Ceased zigzagging, changed course to 288(T), 288(PSC), 280(PSC). Changed speed to 27 knots (280 RPM). Commenced taking station for exercise 1D, (radar tracking). 0510 Made contact with Commander Task Unit THIRTY SIX POINT TWO POINT ONE, range 20 miles, bearing 308(T). 0539 Crew called to general quarters. 0545 Exercise canceled, commenced returning to station to conduct a simulated battle with Task Unit THIRTY SIX POINT TWO POINT ONE. 0640 Battle exercise completed. Task Unit THIRTY SIX POINT TWO POINT ONE forming with Task Unit THIRTY SIX POINT TWO POINT TWO, taking screening station #5, secured from general quarters, set condition II, material condition baker. Course 290(T), 290(PSG), 281(PSC), speed 20 knots (201 RPM). 0720 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 0755 Ceased zigzagging resumed base course. 0756 Changed course to 125(T), 125(PSG), 117(PSC), commenced taking position to pass mail to USS MONTPELIER.

Taking station #4 in screen. 0925 USS PRINGLE closed to deliver mail. 1025 Changed base course to 290(T), (PGC), 281(PSC). 1050 Changed base course to 305(T), (PGC), 297 1/2(PSC). Took station #6. 1058 Commenced zigzagging in plan #12. 1145 Commenced maneuvering for aircraft recovery. 0800 Position: Latitude 13-40-30 S., Longitude 158-38-40 E.
1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1208 Completed maneuvering for aircraft recovery, returned to base course 305(T). 1214 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 1506 Task Unit THIRTY SIX POINT TWO POINT TWO maneuvering to leave THIRTY SIX POINT TWO POINT ONE. 1516 Base course changed to 270(T), 270(PSC), 262(PSC). 1519 Changed speed to 18 knots. 1525 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 1200 Position: Latitude 13-57 S., Longitude 160-50 E.
1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1850 Ceased zigzagging. 1900 Changed base course, to 240(T), (PGC), 231(PSC).
2000-2400 Steaming as before. Position at 2000: Latitude 13-39-00 S., Longitude 158-41-00 E. 2300 Change course to 180(T), 180(PSG), 172(PSC).

0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0500 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #38. 0637 Ceased zigzagging. 0639 Changed base course to 150(T), (PGC), 142(PSC). 0639 Changed speed to 15 knots. 0655 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10 from base course. 0715 Begun delivering mail to USS RENSHAW, USS EATON, USS COLUMBIA, USS DENVER.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. Continued delivering mail. 0819 Ceased zigzagging. 0821 Completed transfer of mail. 0825 Changed base course to 310(T), (PGC), 300(PSC). 0841 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 0850 Ceased zigzagging following various courses ahead of cruisers, changing to formation abeam. 0905 Resumed base course 310(T). 0910 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 1032 Ceased zigzagging. 1035 Changed base course to 130(T), (PGC), 121(PSC). 1048 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 1105 Ceased zigzagging, changed base course to 107(T), (PGC), 097(PSC). 1114 Changed speed to 20 knots. 1116 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #12. 1145 Ceased zigzagging. 1147 Changed base course to 095(T), (PGC), 087 1/2(PSC). 1155 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 0800 Position: Latitude 18-45-00 S., Longitude 159-42-00 E.

1600-2000 Steaming as before. 1845 Ceased zigzagging.
2000-2400 Steaming as before. 2000 Position: Latitude 13-46-00 S., Longitude 162-06-00 E.

0400-0800 Steaming as before. 0520 Crew called to general quarters. Secured boiler #4. 0721 Ceased zigzagging.
0800-1200 Steaming as before. 0800 Changed speed to 25 knots. 0930 Commenced scheduled exercises #13, burst practice. 0946 Ceased scheduled exercise. 1200-1600 Steaming as before. 1208 Changed course to 170(T), (PGC), 161 1/2(PSC). 1215 Changed speed to 25 knots. 1224 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 1330 Changed speed to 18 knots. 1331 Ceased zigzagging. 1345 Changed course to 225(T), (PGC), 216(PSC). 1348 Commenced zigzagging in accordance with plan #10. 1402 Ceased zigzagging. 1417 Changed course to 270(T), 259(PGC). 1405 Steering various courses, screening cruisers while entering channel. 1435 station all special sea detail. 1440 Steering various courses and speeds conforming to channel. 1514 Passed through net at Espiritu Santo.
